AUDIENCE: Trying to
remember exactly. PROFESSOR: Well, I remember. There was, for instance, the--

I don't want to do
that, but I did. There was less of
an entrance in here. AUDIENCE: Right

PROFESSOR: Of course,
this was here, and this has gotten much more
articulate than what it was,

which I need to know about. But this was coming
up and went down. And then we suggested
that it didn't happen out

of the ordinary coming over. That was one thing. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: And we suggested
that the back court, the corner

court, which still is
not got little larger. AUDIENCE: Yeah, it's more open.

It's just, yeah, OK. I see. OK. So right, to make
this entrance bigger

and as matching floats
coming out of here, I just moved the main
volume of this back.
I think I just made it shorter. It was pretty long before.

And then this volume goes from
here to there and ends there. And then that volume starts. So this is the artists
rooms and centers.

And this one is
basically one floor. This one will be three floors.

And so the bottom
floor for both of them is going to be like
the bigger rooms, like a big wood
shop or metal shop

or something that'll be more
directly connected to in here. And then as you grow up,
you get more smaller spaces

for more individual work. And then, as far as
this access goes--

PROFESSOR: I'm going
to let that fall. AUDIENCE: Yeah, I tried
to figure out the stairs. They are still kind of iffy.

But I thought-- well, I thought
it would be interesting, this piece, first of
all, it's actually

step lower than the first
step, but it's on the sidewalk. So instead of
concrete, you'll start

walking on the stone over here. I'm imagining this to be stone. And so you'll be walking on
it without even realizing it,

and then you'll be
brought into it. And I was imagining little
platforms, maybe little pools of water.

So people are
sitting around here, and it's kind of a
nice meeting place. And then it leads you up
to this plane, this floor,

which starts becoming interior
around here wherever the roof kind of lands.

And it's the tourist
information area.

And underneath
here, I was thinking this should be some
of supply store place because, obviously, they're
going to need lots of supplies.

So I thought that'd be a
good place for that to go. And then from here, they
can come up to this.

This is a roof deck. This actually is
just holding it up. Somehow, this will
be held up like this. PROFESSOR: You go under.

AUDIENCE: Yeah, so you can
walk all the way across here, and there'll be food
up here and everything.

And then you can, I'm thinking
of maybe a little bridge or something to get into here.

And this, I was thinking, would
be some sort of a theater, like a movie theater or--

PROFESSOR: This block? AUDIENCE: Yeah, it's
actually pretty tall, so I think you'd have
one for a bigger theater and like a small lecture
hall or something

so you could show Italian
classics or something. I don't know.

And then, as far as this
plane, you can get on to it from in here.

So I'm not quite sure if these
two will be connected so you can go from here to here.
[? But ?] it will definitely

[? be like ?] come
out on both of those. And then the way-- PROFESSOR: Let's put
this back so that-- because I can-- yeah, go on.

AUDIENCE: And then the way
these spaces here work, this one is kind of nice.

You can enter it right
from the street in here. And there'll probably be an
entrance [? to the ?] theater back here so you can watch the
movie, come out here and rest.

Whatever I do with the water
has sort of happened again here. And then this space, it's
actually pretty open.

All of this is just
[INAUDIBLE] this building into. So it's all that. I just gave it a
little bit of a fluke.

So it's more of
the personal space for the artists, which is then
very much connected to here.

But this will be
at the evening, can be full of people coming to the
movie, coming to eat up here.

And then you can go back
there, and it'll be more quiet. And as far as the roof
is going, I'm imagining--

you can kind of see it, but
just a bunch of planes kind

of connecting or intersecting. I'm going to put
the pieces on here.

See better so you have
[INAUDIBLE] this one plane here

and another one,
basically, go down. PROFESSOR: Mm-hmm. AUDIENCE: I didn't want
anything curved or anything,

so I'm trying to keep the planes
and keep varying the levels. PROFESSOR: Mm-hmm. AUDIENCE: I would say
it's not very defined yet.

PROFESSOR: I can understand. AUDIENCE: This way. And so then the columns will
help define interior spaces

better. PROFESSOR: A couple
of questions. Do I come across the
street here and down?

AUDIENCE: No, I hadn't-- it doesn't completely
reach across the street.

So I didn't have that as-- PROFESSOR: OK, but it's a
platform that comes out. AUDIENCE: It's a platform. Yeah, you can come out on it.

PROFESSOR: And of course,
I can go under it. AUDIENCE: Right, right. PROFESSOR: But I want
to review a little bit.

Part of this project is
building nature in the city. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: How are
you doing that?

AUDIENCE: Yeah, so I feel that
the outdoor areas of this,

this, this, this will
all have elements of--

well, this is all
stone, first of all. So that's with the ground on it. And then I want to incorporate
some pools of water,

things like that into here
that I haven't figured out very much. PROFESSOR: OK. AUDIENCE: And then
also, this structure

I'm kind of thinking it
should be wood because, not only is it more organic, but
the floats that are being built

are probably out of wood, so
kind of really a little bit. So I think through the
materials and the colors

that I'm going to try to
use, stone, wood, water. So it won't be big,
massive trees and stuff,

but it'll be more just
through the materials. PROFESSOR: Mm-hmm. All right, again,
I think everybody

is settling into a general
organization, which is good, and particularly,
the change of this and also

the use of this, which is kind
of a perfect use, in a way, related to this, of the
theater because then, in terms

of the elevation, I can do
something related to that. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: So the
ordinary is moving into this extremely
extraordinary thing
that you have. Three issues at least.

The first is that
you gave a big clue when you said
you're going to make this in the street
a different paving.

AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: What I
think should happen, picking up on what
you just said,

is what I call the building
of the mind meaning that the building starts
long before I get there.

AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: That this triangular
condition might actually stretch down the street even
farther than what you have

and be exactly-- I can't do it with this--
but be exactly what you said.

But down in here,
I start to realize that I'm in a territory which
is part of this building and is not part
of something else.

But just a slight
change, that perhaps that starts to elevate just slightly.

AUDIENCE: Uh-huh. PROFESSOR: So I'm
starting to move up. So when I get to
here, I'm almost,

as I have it here, at the
same level where there's going to be a wall here, obviously. AUDIENCE: Right.

PROFESSOR: The reason
I say that is that-- and the reason I ask you
the question about nature--

is that there could
be the beginning of some kind of continuous
natural experience, which

could be trees or water. For instance, water
could be moving down through this along the way.

And maybe there's a pool. I know we're in the street,
but still it could be--

the street's over here, so there
might be enough room to do it, so that the water is the
thing that ties it together

in this case. And the trees are the thing
that ties it together. So I'm moving up. AUDIENCE: Right.

PROFESSOR: Now, the places
that I have problems with that, if that's the case--

and I think that's what
you're trying to do, and that's what you told me-- is that it seems
very, very gentle

and just the right
change of elevation and here and maybe over here.

But here it's very abrupt. AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: And
there may be a way that you can make
that transition

from this vertical-- horizontal
to this one in a vertical way, not like this, of course, but
a little less abrupt so that I

can move up more slowly. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: If that's the
case, then conceptually, what you've always
talked about is

relating it to the street this
way and relating it this way.

Then there's a
crossing of the two, and just as you've shown on
your model, one's gray and one's copper, we would recognize
it as that crossing.

Whereas, that's why I ask you. This one might be a overpass
with a spiral stair or a stair

that I can get over
and up through. AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: And it's
different than this one,

but the two are
crossing each one. One is natural. One is more urban.

That's the first thing. The second thing is that you
solved a problem, I think, from last time in terms of the
entrance and, in the process,

created a problem. And I'll explain why. You've got a very nice
entrance in the sense of space.

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: Huh? AUDIENCE: I have
[INAUDIBLE] over here. PROFESSOR: Well, you
do, but assuming that

you can deal with that. No, I'm more concerned
about it being very dark. AUDIENCE: Yeah, right.

OK, let me tell-- these I was actually imagining
translucent materials

so that you can see people
working, et cetera, which would also help with the
light so they wouldn't

be these dark cardboard. PROFESSOR: But that's only
on the lower level though.

AUDIENCE: No, sort of
the whole volume almost. I'm just picturing this
translucent completely

like these volumes. And then, so I don't know
if that helps [INAUDIBLE]..

PROFESSOR: Well, it does. Well, what I'm trying to get
is some light down into this somehow, where this maybe
comes slightly smaller here so

that there's a vertical
shaft of light that's anchoring the space at the
place where you need it

the most, which is the corner. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: So that,
when I'm here, like a moth towards
a light bulb,

I'm drawn towards
the light, to there. And then once I'm there,
I'm drawn into there.

AUDIENCE: Right, I guess
I was going directly-- like I was [INAUDIBLE]. PROFESSOR: Yeah, which
is good, and that's
the secondary part of it. But I'm talking about just-- I'm not so sure--

in spite of everything
you said, but I'm still a little concerned
that the space is pretty good size without
light coming from above.

AUDIENCE: Right, OK. PROFESSOR: But I don't
think that's a major change.

I think that's a slight
change in the organization. And I think it's in that point.

AUDIENCE: There is. There's space between this plane
and that building [INAUDIBLE].. PROFESSOR: Yeah, you
could do that too, yeah. And even better
because then the light

would come down
and wash that wall. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: So you get
light down into the space, and it's washing the wall
at the same time, which

is what would be the best
because, when I'm out here, then I see that daylight hitting
the side of the wall coming
down. OK, now, the biggie. Ready? AUDIENCE: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: The way
you explained this, and the way these guys
are sitting here-- and I know they're just
taped up and all that,

which are quite beautiful-- but the immediate
reaction that I

have to it, which I want
you to just consider. There is a configuration
underneath this

of geometric forms which
producing the space is all things we've talked about. In reality, what
you've done is you've

put like leafs on top
of this to cover it.
And you talked about-- I probably can't do it-- different heights of these.

AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: OK? But unfortunately, it's a bit
like a crossword puzzle here.

This one should
go under that one, probably, in order
to make it work. Can I do that? No, I can't. No, I can't.

I'm going to-- can
I take this off? AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: OK.

So these are like petals,
and you want to cover these.

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] and stuff. PROFESSOR: And glass, but
there are different levels. AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: Just for the moment,
imagine there's no columns.

Instead, there's tension
going up onto the wall.

So this part of
the building, which is what I would call sky
form, is, in fact, separated,

to a certain extent, from this. And it's acting like
a tent-like covering.

Therefore, no
column's going down. And therefore, where this
is meeting the other,

is a glass partition, obviously,
but it's free to meet. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: Well, underneath--
this is a space, obviously.

So the line of the
wall might, say,

coming up against this
form underneath, hit here. And it might zig back and
hit this one and zig back

and hit that one, zig
back and hit this one. AUDIENCE: Right, oh, OK. Yeah.

PROFESSOR: So the
walls, which are glass. I would assume you
meant are transparent.

And it's being held up with
cables, which it can be done.

And at night, this is
like a little-- and this might be copper roofs. I don't know what it is. It's light metal maybe or glass.

Or maybe it doesn't
have to be glass. Maybe it's just the
light coming through it-- is, at night, I see this glow
underneath of these forms

coming off this building. AUDIENCE: Oh, I like that. PROFESSOR: And therefore,
I don't have a forest

of columns coming down through. AUDIENCE: Yeah, I was kind
of worried about having [INAUDIBLE]. PROFESSOR: Well, the point is
that-- you see, there's two--

I think there are
two structures here. I think there's this,
and then there's this.

And so by not having
columns, I don't have to try to get those
columns down through that.

AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: And I know that
David can help you on this, but I know that we can
do that architecturally.

We can hang these guys. And by the way, it might
look very beautiful

if I saw a bunch of
cables coming across--  AUDIENCE: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: --with
the roofs on top. AUDIENCE: Uh-huh. PROFESSOR: Now, does that-- AUDIENCE: Yeah, I like that.

PROFESSOR: Does that-- AUDIENCE: Because I just imagine
just floating [? lighting-- ?] PROFESSOR: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: --and stuff. PROFESSOR: Well, I think
that's what you imagine them as floating. But if they got columns on them,
they're not exactly floating.

It's still OK, but it's
not quite the same. AUDIENCE: Oh, OK. PROFESSOR: So think about
that one before you do it.

But it might make your
idea even stronger.

AUDIENCE: Yeah, I like it. PROFESSOR: We've got a
troublesome spot here

that I think you can solve. AUDIENCE: Yeah, I think the
opening of that right there might have-- PROFESSOR: And by the
way, if that's up there,

then I have more to-- I can play more with that. I think the land form needs
to be more articulate.

AUDIENCE: Uh-huh, [INAUDIBLE]. PROFESSOR: Yeah,
getting up through. And the copper passageway--

for instance, this
might come down. It might be narrower
and narrower, and then it comes down to the
other side of the street, which

should be about there. AUDIENCE: OK. PROFESSOR: And by the
way, there's a wall--

I'm saying somewhere
in here you start up, but there's also a wall in here. AUDIENCE: Yeah, [INAUDIBLE].

PROFESSOR: But it may not be
as high as that, of course. AUDIENCE: Right. PROFESSOR: So what it is that
I'm moving down the street

and I'm slowly making a
transition from the street into this world of yours. And I may not even I do it.

AUDIENCE: Yeah, I wanted
them to be like, oh, wait. I didn't want to
be on the steps. PROFESSOR: Right, but
then all of a sudden I find this incredible thing.

They're working and
they're building this unbelievable
float that I can see.

So what you need
to do now is to-- beyond what I just said
is also start to make

some articulation of what the
materials are, or at least, not materials at this stage, but
at least opaque, transparent,

translucent. AUDIENCE: Yeah, not this. PROFESSOR: By the way,
this is open, is it not? AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: Yeah, which
I think it should be.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: Yeah, it's outdoor. It's not here. AUDIENCE: Right, exactly.

PROFESSOR: I think
it's neat, and I think it's
interesting because it has a relationship to
your previous projects.

In a strange way, it's the
billboard on it's side. It's the sails
floating, and it's

kind of like it's a summary of
both projects that you've done. AUDIENCE: OK. PROFESSOR: So go to it.

AUDIENCE: I guess I started
from the plan and tried to do-- like use the existing
lines to create the shapes

for the planes in
my different floors. And so a lot of them
came out of being

perpendicular to the
building or parallel to, or perpendicular or
parallel to the street.

And then, from there,
I just kind of cut them and kept trying to figure
out what shapes would

work with the program
and circulation and compositionally, I guess. And this is what I came up with.

So it's kind of I was
imagining like the bottom floor

to be where the restaurant is. And there's this
access from the back

also, so you can go
directly from the bottom. And also, it's the ambiguous. Is it the skate park, or is it
[? for the function of the ?]

building? And then it's kind of hard
to see with it like this,

PROFESSOR: No, but I can see it. Don't take it apart. AUDIENCE: But it's [INAUDIBLE]
transition space still

also from the two spaces. And then I focused on having-- I figured a lot of people
would spend a lot of time--

I wanted to integrate the
skating aspect and the rock climbing aspect more,
because the way I had it

before it was kind of just like
skating on or below the grade. And then the building
was rock climbing.

So I wanted to bring in
more of the skating into it. So I had a 1/2 pipe in there,
which I figured a lot of people

would spend a lot of time in. It's more stationary
of a skating area

since you're staying within it. And then, the part
where you come up is kind of has a
relationship to this part

down here where the largest
rock climbing center wall is, where people would
be standing here.

It took away that
people were climbing. So you have the rock
climbers and skaters

being able to see more
of what's going on between the two activities.

And then I also had mentioned
in the pin-up for the posters

that I had wanted
an area where people could learn how to rock climb. PROFESSOR: Oh, mm-hmm.

AUDIENCE: So I see this
center being like-- so the wall extends
all the way through, but it'll be a smaller
wall for lessons and stuff,

but you could also
see the main wall. So I guess everything
kind of ended up

being focused around
being able to always have a view of
these two activities

but being as open to the
outside as possible also. And I haven't done the--

I'm working on seeing
what full walls I want. And so I started
doing the railing

so I could put it in the
main wall to start to take-- how the outer shell
should take form.

Right now, I see it as being-- because I purposely-- I wanted
to have a lot of faces to it,

kind of like how I talked
about in my presentation

as having the skate
area suggest the pools

in the water and
fluidity, and then the building more of a mass.

So kind of how the-- how [? rock slides. ?] I wanted
it to have a lot of faces,

each face having different
material maybe according to what I see [INAUDIBLE].

And so I think these
different edges will provide that and have
sunlight coming in and

[? out. ?] PROFESSOR: Mm-hmm. AUDIENCE: I'm just not
sure how exactly I'm

going to do it,
like if I'm going to have this be inside
to outside structure,

or have it like
have on the inside. Or I did have these kind of
on here as the different areas

that I might have, like have
this be one intersection

and then like this another
and then this another. So they'd be at
different levels. But I haven't quite
figured that out yet.

I'm not sure about
if I want to have-- and then I wanted to be in
as much light as possible,

of course. So those are all the
different factors I'm trying to consider when I
do the walls and roof, I guess.

PROFESSOR: And this is outside. AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: And of course,
this one is outside. But most likely, this is outside
too, most likely, or not?

AUDIENCE: No, that's like
the inside right now. PROFESSOR: So I'm inside, and
then I go outside here somehow. AUDIENCE: Yeah, there'd
be a door right here.

PROFESSOR: OK.  OK, and then inside,
I think I see it,

but there's a set of
steps that kind of take me from here to here and
then from there to there. AUDIENCE: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: Basically, there's
only really three levels in it. There's one below it,
but there's three levels.

AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: I'm getting up
[? through. ?] Where do I-- I don't this building.

I have never been here before. How do I know where to come in? AUDIENCE: Well, I was going
to have this area be solid,

like how that one is,
or less transparent. So you can also climb in it.

Right PROFESSOR: Here. AUDIENCE: Yeah, and then
this would be very-- and [INAUDIBLE] had it
tilted, slanted this way.

So most of the traffic
is coming this way. So you will be able to see
steps and the clear, maybe

automatic doors. And then I was hoping that this
would catch people's attention, being able to see this
inside the building

and wanting to go look at it. And then the pattern
on the floor,

following it out over
here, and I guess, all kind of a reception place here,
and then the food place.

So from that angle, I
kind see it like that. And hopefully, from any of the
angles, you see the [INAUDIBLE]
coming out.  PROFESSOR: OK, I got it.

First of all, it's a
great jump from Tuesday. And making it smaller by that
factor but bigger than this one

is just, to me, about the
right size for the right side. The other thing that you had
but we didn't see it entirely,

which I think is
really powerful here, is this bridge or
this lookout acting

as kind of a continuity
around the building and even to the point where,
if we could see

another one of these
someplace over here, if that were possible so
that, these being outside,

I go into the building
and I come out and I see different views. This one was the viewing
platform from way back,

but maybe there's
another one over there, or maybe there's one even
from the second floor. AUDIENCE: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: But that's all-- to me, that's very
strong, this part.

The other part that's
strong is the landscape that's being created because
of this, which is beautiful,

underneath this. This is terrific. And here, and the
copper tube, I think,

it's great because
you'd be standing here, and you wouldn't know what
would be coming in or out. Somebody would come in through.

AUDIENCE: Just hear
the noise there. PROFESSOR: You'd hear
the noise and then, wow, that'd come through, which would
be, I think, very powerful.

So it seems to me that
the landscape issue of this and the building
are integrated very well,

and by the way, much better
than it was the other day when you were talking with curves. AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: It's the
wrong way to go, I think.

A couple of things
that I see, that just bring to your attention. AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm.

PROFESSOR: I am still somewhat
bothered by the notion that the little kids are
over here hanging out

at the very edge of
the site, so to speak, and the big kids stop-- I assume, go around
here and come back.

AUDIENCE: Well, I was
kind of seeing this as a transition space between
two different kinds of skating,

like the pool skating, and then
more like the street trick-- you can do street
tricks skating.

It'll be more like
rails and steps, that kind of like slower speed. PROFESSOR: OK, so not
necessarily little kids

as opposed to big kids. AUDIENCE: Yeah, little
kids just so in the sense that this is all very high speed
and a little more dangerous,

I guess. But this still has the
slopes they can work on. But the big kids
would go here to work

on the street skating anyway. It's just not as high speed
as this area, I guess.

PROFESSOR: Well, fine. Another way of
doing it, however, would have been
not to do that here but to do that someplace else,
like back there or even inside

and let this thing become
much more of a counterbalance to the other side so that I
would come out of this tube

and around and then,
I would assume, back into the building and around.

If that's a
possibility, that it's more of a continuous
surface, if I got it right. Is it right that I
could, in theory,

go from here through the
building and come out? AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: So the notion of
almost this figure eight kind

of notion coming
through the building.  Might be another
way of doing it,

which means that
this is not here. A comment or two that
I think is not good.

These guys look like
leftover places, these seats and this wall.

Not nearly as integrated
into the landscape, say, as what you're doing
in here or even there,

which is very powerful. The mountain or the climbing
wall there, this one,

is very strong. It could be higher,
it seems to me.

AUDIENCE: I'm going to have a-- I don't know what
happened to it. I used to have a screen.

PROFESSOR: Oh, that's right. There's a screen up there. OK, terrific. OK, so then maybe if
there was a screen there,

we don't have it higher. But I was going to
suggest it could be narrower and a little
higher and still do

that because it's taking up
quite a bit of the land here.

AUDIENCE: Narrower this way? PROFESSOR: Yeah, narrower
that way, vertically.

I don't know how you
justify my concern yet-- oh, I do know how you do it--

of wanting to make the
connection between the ordinary and the extraordinary. This face is not
necessarily climbing.

It's this face. So therefore, this
could be some kind of-- AUDIENCE: Oh, yeah,
that was [INAUDIBLE]..

PROFESSOR: --a
wall that's coming in from the ordinary of this. And then, wow.

All of a sudden, in fact, AUDIENCE: Turn the corner. PROFESSOR: Yeah, I
turned the corner. In fact, this could go
even a little bit farther

making this world
just a little bit more hidden than what you've got
because I don't use that face.

AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm. PROFESSOR: Now,
that's one thing. The second thing
is that this is a--

if I'm not mistaken-- is
an inside climbing wall. It, all of a sudden now, looks
very token and very small

in relationship to the space. AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: It seems like it
could have been much larger

or even be more commanding
in size for the space that you have inside. AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm.

PROFESSOR: Assuming that
it works for the climbers. So it could become much more
of an architectural issue,

as this one is, by
